trans-unit.source: Create a virtual machine running Linux in Azure
trans-unit.target: Create a virtual machine running Linux in Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn to create Azure virtual machine (VM) running Linux by using an image from Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn to create Azure virtual machine (VM) running Linux by using an image from Azure.

trans-unit.source: Creating an Azure virtual machine (VM) that runs Linux is easy to do from the command line or from the portal.
trans-unit.target: Creating an Azure virtual machine (VM) that runs Linux is easy to do from the command line or from the portal.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to use the Azure Command-Line Interface for Mac, Linux, and Windows (the Azure CLI) to create quickly an Ubuntu Server VM running in Azure, connect to it using ssh, and creating and mounting a new disk.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to use the Azure Command-Line Interface for Mac, Linux, and Windows (the Azure CLI) to create quickly an Ubuntu Server VM running in Azure, connect to it using ssh, and creating and mounting a new disk.

trans-unit.source: (This topic uses an Ubuntu Server VM, but you can also create Linux VMs using <linkText>your own images as templates</linkText><title></title>.)
trans-unit.target: (This topic uses an Ubuntu Server VM, but you can also create Linux VMs using <linkText>your own images as templates</linkText><title></title>.)

trans-unit.source: Here's a walkthrough of this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Here's a walkthrough of this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.VIDEO building-a-linux-virtual-machine-tutorial]
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.VIDEO building-a-linux-virtual-machine-tutorial]

trans-unit.source: The first step is to <linkText>install the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The first step is to <linkText>install the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Good.
trans-unit.target: Good.

trans-unit.source: Now make sure you're in the resource management mode by typing azure config mode arm.
trans-unit.target: Now make sure you're in the resource management mode by typing azure config mode arm.

trans-unit.source: Even better.
trans-unit.target: Even better.

trans-unit.source: Now log in with your work or school id by typing azure login and following the prompts.
trans-unit.target: Now log in with your work or school id by typing azure login and following the prompts.

trans-unit.source: If you receive an error logging in, you may need to <linkText>create a work or school id from your personal Microsoft account</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you receive an error logging in, you may need to <linkText>create a work or school id from your personal Microsoft account</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Type azure group create westus replacing <my-group-name> with a group name that's unique to you (you can use a different region if you want). You should see something like the following:
trans-unit.target: Type azure group create westus replacing <my-group-name> with a group name that's unique to you (you can use a different region if you want). You should see something like the following:

trans-unit.source: Now create your VM by typing azure vm quick-create, and you'll receive prompts to input the remaining parameters.
trans-unit.target: Now create your VM by typing azure vm quick-create, and you'll receive prompts to input the remaining parameters.

trans-unit.source: Use the name of the resource group that you just created, above, and for the ImageURN value, use canonical:ubuntuserver:14.04.2-LTS:latest, so that your experience looks something like:
trans-unit.target: Use the name of the resource group that you just created, above, and for the ImageURN value, use canonical:ubuntuserver:14.04.2-LTS:latest, so that your experience looks something like:

trans-unit.source: Your VM is up and running and waiting for you to connect.
trans-unit.target: Your VM is up and running and waiting for you to connect.

trans-unit.source: With Linux VMs, you typically connect using ssh.
trans-unit.target: With Linux VMs, you typically connect using ssh.

trans-unit.source: This topic connects to a VM using usernames and passwords; to use public and private key pairs to communicate with your VM, see <linkText>How to Use SSH with Linux on Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This topic connects to a VM using usernames and passwords; to use public and private key pairs to communicate with your VM, see <linkText>How to Use SSH with Linux on Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you're not familiar with connecting with ssh, the command takes the form ssh @ -p . In this case, we use the username and password from the previous step and port 22, which is the default ssh port.
trans-unit.target: If you're not familiar with connecting with ssh, the command takes the form ssh @ -p . In this case, we use the username and password from the previous step and port 22, which is the default ssh port.

trans-unit.source: Now that you're connected to your VM, you're ready to attach a disk.
trans-unit.target: Now that you're connected to your VM, you're ready to attach a disk.

trans-unit.source: Attaching a new disk is quick. Just type azure vm disk attach-new to create and attach a new GB disk for your VM. It should look something like this:
trans-unit.target: Attaching a new disk is quick. Just type azure vm disk attach-new to create and attach a new GB disk for your VM. It should look something like this:

trans-unit.source: Now let's find the disk, using dmesg | grep SCSI (the method you use to discover your new disk may vary).
trans-unit.target: Now let's find the disk, using dmesg | grep SCSI (the method you use to discover your new disk may vary).

trans-unit.source: In this case, it looks something like:
trans-unit.target: In this case, it looks something like:

trans-unit.source: and in the case of this topic, the sdc disk is the one that we want.
trans-unit.target: and in the case of this topic, the sdc disk is the one that we want.

trans-unit.source: Now partition the disk with sudo fdisk /dev/sdc -- assuming that in your case the disk was sdc, and make it a primary disk on partition 1, and accept the other defaults.
trans-unit.target: Now partition the disk with sudo fdisk /dev/sdc -- assuming that in your case the disk was sdc, and make it a primary disk on partition 1, and accept the other defaults.

trans-unit.source: Create the partition by typing p at the prompt:
trans-unit.target: Create the partition by typing p at the prompt:

trans-unit.source: And write a file system to the partition by using the mkfs command, specifying your filesystem type and the device name.
trans-unit.target: And write a file system to the partition by using the mkfs command, specifying your filesystem type and the device name.

trans-unit.source: In this topic, we're using ext4 and /dev/sdc1 from above:
trans-unit.target: In this topic, we're using ext4 and /dev/sdc1 from above:

trans-unit.source: Now we create a directory to mount the file system using mkdir:
trans-unit.target: Now we create a directory to mount the file system using mkdir:

trans-unit.source: And you mount the directory using mount:
trans-unit.target: And you mount the directory using mount:

trans-unit.source: The data disk is now ready to use as /datadrive.
trans-unit.target: The data disk is now ready to use as /datadrive.

trans-unit.source: You can also connect to your Linux virtual machine using an SSH key for identification.
trans-unit.target: You can also connect to your Linux virtual machine using an SSH key for identification.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <linkText>How to Use SSH with Linux on Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <linkText>How to Use SSH with Linux on Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Remember, that your new disk will not typically be available to the VM if it reboots unless you write that information to your <linkText>fstab</linkText><title></title> file.
trans-unit.target: Remember, that your new disk will not typically be available to the VM if it reboots unless you write that information to your <linkText>fstab</linkText><title></title> file.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about Linux on Azure, see:
trans-unit.target: To learn more about Linux on Azure, see:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Linux and Open-Source Computing on Azure</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Linux and Open-Source Computing on Azure</linkText><title></title>
